name.en: College of Information and Computing Sciences

history.en:
The College of Information and Computing Sciences is one of the premier colleges in the province for IT Education and services. It aims to produce competitive IT professionals and IT-enabled individuals who will encourage real innovation for the advancement in the digital era of the province and the country as a whole.
The college was established in 1998 at MSC Boac Campus through BOT Resolution No. 35, s. 1998 as Institute of Information and Computing Sciences (IICS), a special program to offer Associate in Computer Technology (ACT). Believing that the province needs IT Human Resources, after two years, IICS was adopted as the School of Information and Computing Sciences (SICS), offering two emerging degree programs Bachelor of Science in Information Management and Bachelor of Science in Information Technology to cater to the graduates of ACT. Bachelor of Science in Information Management was also offered in Sta. Cruz Campus. The Bachelor of Science in Information Management (BSIM) was renamed to the Bachelor of Science in Information Systems (BSIS) to adapt to CHED Memorandum Order No. 53 series of 2006.
After a decade, the Marinduque State College had an organizational restructuring wherein two of the big schools in the college were merged. The School of Industrial Technology and the School of Information and Computing Sciences convergence paved the way for the School of Technology's birth in 2016. After three years of being together, the two schools parted ways due to another organizational restructuring and SICS was re-birth in 2019.
In 2021, however, SICS was converted to the Institute of Information Systems and Technology (IIST) and became part of the College of Engineering, Information and Industrial Technology (CEIIT) together with the Institute of Engineering and Department of Industrial Technology to centralize the resources of these three into a single college. But once again, fate has plans for this institute and let it navigate its ship on its own. Finally, the former school was converted into a college, banning the name of the College of Information and Computing Sciences (CICS).
In 25 years of its existence, CICS has contributed significantly to MSC's mandates in Instruction, Research, Extension, and Production. Currently, both the BS in Information Systems and BS in Information Technology in Boac Campus are Level III Re-Accredited by the Accrediting Agency of Chartered Colleges and Universities in the Philippines (AACCUP), while the BS in Information Systems in Sta. Cruz Campus is Level II Re-Accredited. CICS has produced thousands of IT professionals serving in the province, other parts of the country, and even the global industry. Faculty and students are also actively engaged in research through various local and international presentations and publications. CICS also serves the community by providing relevant extension projects and activities.
For the years to come, CICS still commits to giving what their stakeholders deserve through quality education and public service with their mantra, 'WORK IN SILENCE AND LET OUR SUCCESS MAKE OUR NOISE!'

goals.en: To produce competitive IT professionals and IT enabled individuals who will encourage real innovation for the advancement in the digital era of the province and the country as a whole.

objectives.en:
To provide quality education in Information and Computing Sciences that will produce globally competitive graduates.
To conduct relevant research in Information and Computing Sciences that will contribute to the advancement of knowledge and technology.
To extend services to the community through information and computing sciences that will uplift the quality of life of the people.

title.en: MARSU Conducts Its 69th Annual Commencement Exercise Class 2025

description.en: The Marinduque State University (MARSU) held its 69th Annual Commencement Exercise for the Class of 2025 on June 14, 2025, at the MSC Boac Campus.

content.en: As we look back on this special day, we honor the graduates of the College of Information and Computing Sciences, those who pushed through every challenge, stayed up late to finish projects, and kept going even when things got tough this moment is proof that all the hard work was worth it. From sleepless nights to moments of victory, they finally made it !.

title.en: A Legendary Send-off

description.en: A legendary send-off for the graduating class of 2025.

content.en:
It‚Äôs never easy to say goodbye to people who helped shape what a team truly means.
To our graduates ‚Äî thank you. You were more than your roles. You were the ones behind the camera, behind the sketches, behind the sound checks. You were there when things got tough, when events popped up out of nowhere, when we had to run from one building to another with barely any rest. You still showed up, even if your house was far, even if your body was tired, even if the weather wasn‚Äôt on our side.
You captured moments, made people feel seen, and gave meaning to the smallest details. And you didn‚Äôt ask for recognition ‚Äî you simply did what needed to be done, and you did it with heart.
Barney once said, ‚Äúùòûùò©ùò¢ùòµùò¶ùò∑ùò¶ùò≥ ùò∫ùò∞ùò∂ ùò•ùò∞ ùò™ùòØ ùòµùò©ùò™ùò¥ ùò≠ùò™ùòßùò¶, ùò™ùòµ‚Äôùò¥ ùòØùò∞ùòµ ùò≠ùò¶ùò®ùò¶ùòØùò•ùò¢ùò≥ùò∫ ùò∂ùòØùò≠ùò¶ùò¥ùò¥ ùò∫ùò∞ùò∂ùò≥ ùòßùò≥ùò™ùò¶ùòØùò•ùò¥ ùò¢ùò≥ùò¶ ùòµùò©ùò¶ùò≥ùò¶ ùòµùò∞ ùò¥ùò¶ùò¶ ùò™ùòµ.‚Äù And we were here to witness it ‚Äî the late nights, the technical hiccups, the creative rushes, the laughter in between. It wasn‚Äôt always perfect, but it was real. It was honest. And it was legendary because you were part of it.
We‚Äôve always worked in the moment ‚Äî live coverage, real-time adjustments, no time for rewrites. And that‚Äôs also how this goodbye feels. Sudden. Fast. But meaningful.
Robin once said, ‚Äúùòõùò©ùò¶ ùòßùò∂ùòµùò∂ùò≥ùò¶ ùò™ùò¥ ùò¥ùò§ùò¢ùò≥ùò∫, ùò£ùò∂ùòµ ùò∫ùò∞ùò∂ ùò§ùò¢ùòØ‚Äôùòµ ùò´ùò∂ùò¥ùòµ ùò≥ùò∂ùòØ ùò£ùò¢ùò§ùò¨ ùòµùò∞ ùòµùò©ùò¶ ùò±ùò¢ùò¥ùòµ ùò£ùò¶ùò§ùò¢ùò∂ùò¥ùò¶ ùò™ùòµ‚Äôùò¥ ùòßùò¢ùòÆùò™ùò≠ùò™ùò¢ùò≥.‚Äù And while it‚Äôs sad to let go of this chapter, we know you‚Äôre ready for what‚Äôs next. You‚Äôve already proven how strong, passionate, and reliable you are. And whatever comes after this, we know you‚Äôll carry those same values forward.
You‚Äôre graduating, but your presence stays with us. In every shoot we do, every layout we polish, every small thing we learned from you ‚Äî you‚Äôll be there, too.
From all of us still here, thank you for the patience, the guidance, the small talks during long days, and for choosing to stay, even when it was hard.
You‚Äôve made your mark. You‚Äôll always be part of our story.
With love and pride,
Infocus Family

title.en: Happy Independence Day

description.en: Celebrating the bravery and sacrifices of Filipinos during the revolution.

content.en: When the revolution broke out in 1896, Filipinos risked their lives to fight for freedom from the colonizers. One of the key figures in the Philippine Revolution who offered shelter, food, and medical aid to the Katipunan revolutionaries was Melchora Aquino, known as Tandang Sora. She was also honored with the titles ‚ÄúMother of the Katipunan‚Äù and ‚ÄúGrand Woman of the Revolution.‚Äù As a supporter of the Katipunan, she provided them with rice and cattle for food, as spotted in the photo. #RP612fic

outcomes.outcome: Demonstrate broad and coherent knowledge and understanding in the core areas of information systems, including systems analysis and design, database management, networking, and information security. Apply critical thinking and problem-solving skills to analyze complex information systems problems and develop effective solutions. Design, implement, and manage information systems that meet organizational needs while adhering to ethical standards and legal requirements. Communicate effectively with diverse audiences, both orally and in writing, to convey technical information related to information systems. Work collaboratively in teams to achieve common goals in the development and implementation of information systems projects. Demonstrate a commitment to lifelong learning by staying current with emerging technologies and trends in the field of information systems.

Define and access information needs; assess and organize information and knowledge. Produce, share and utilize information and knowledge. Communicate in different formats and platforms (print, broadcast, and online). Prepare communication/media plan. Conduct communication and media research and evaluation. Develop and produce communication materials in different formats and platforms. Demonstrate communication management and leadership skills. Develop entrepreneurial capabilities. Adhere to ethical standards and practices. Know and practice rights and responsibilities and accountabilities in the communication profession. Demonstrate a development orientation in communication work. Apply communication theories/models, principles, practices, and tools in development work.

headline.en: UP Scientists to Lecture on Geohazards at Boac‚Äôs Casa Real

lead.en: UP Diliman‚Äôs NIGS team arrives in Marinduque ahead of their June 28 lecture series on geohazards, promoting local awareness and preparedness.

body.en:
19 June 2025 | A group of faculty & students from UP Diliman‚Äôs National Institute of Geological Sciences (NIGS), is given the traditional Marinduque√±o welcome  by Mar S U‚Äôs VPRE Dr. Ma. Edelwina M. Blas√©, VPAF Atty. Crispin Francis M. Jandusay (representing University President, Prof. Diosdado P. Zulueta) with faculty members from the College of Environmental Studies, and MarSU students. The group is here to deliver a series of lectures on Geohazards at the Casa Real on Saturday, 28 June 2025.  
Led by Associate Prof. Leo T. Armada, PhD, they intend to help ‚Äúraise awareness & a deeper understanding of geologic processes and geohazard risks specific to Marinduque‚Äù. Teachers of Earth Sciences, Disaster Preparedness personnel, Environmental Science students and other relevant practitioners are very much welcome to attend. 
Earlier in the week, Mar S U also welcomed scientists from UP Los Ba√±os & experts from the United Kingdom‚Äôs  National Oceanographic Center, who are here to conduct an assessment of Marinduque‚Äôs coastline to check on its status after several decades since the Marcopper mining disaster of 1996. 
Marinduque State University has signed an MOU with the University of the Philippines Los Ba√±os to be one of its collaborative research partners.

headline.en: Faculty in In-Service Training 2025 - Day 1: Strenghtening Instructional Excellence

lead.en: Marinduque State University kicked off its 2025 Faculty In-Service Training on June 18, featuring expert talks and workshops focused on outcomes-based, learner-centered instruction.

body.en:
Marinduque State University officially commenced the Faculty In-Service Training 2025 on June 18, 2025, at the MarSU Gymnasium. The opening ceremony featured welcome remarks from Ms. Erma E. Reyes, Supervising Administrative Officer, setting the stage for a productive and insightful program. Additionally, an official message from University President Dr. Diosdado P. Zulueta, delivered by Atty. Crispin Francis M. Jandusay, Vice President for Administration & Finance, reaffirmed the university‚Äôs commitment to academic advancement and instructional innovation. Shortly after, Asst. Prof. Raoul J. Magcamit introduced the Day 1 Resource Speaker.  
The program continued with an insightful lecture by Dr. Josephine M. Calamlam, Professor III at PNU-Manila, focusing on the development of pedagogically-sound, learner-centered, and outcomes-based instructional materials. The afternoon session transitioned into a structured lecture-discussion and guided development workshop, providing participants with the opportunity to apply key principles in instructional material design. 
 A productive and enriching start to this professional development initiative, reaffirming Marinduque State University‚Äôs dedication to academic excellence and innovation.

headline.en: Marinduque State University Joins Times Higher Education World University Rankings 2025

lead.en: MARSU has been officially listed in the Times Higher Education World University Rankings for 2025, marking a significant milestone in its academic journey.

body.en:
MarSU earns global recognition for its commitment to sustainable and inclusive development
Boac, Marinduque, Philippines Marinduque State University (MarSU), under the leadership of Prof. Dr. Diosdado P. Zulueta, proudly makes its debut in the Times Higher Education (THE) World University Rankings 2025, marking a historic milestone not only for the institution but also for the Province of Marinduque and the MIMAROPA Region.
The THE World University Rankings, established in 2010, is one of the most prestigious global performance assessments for higher education institutions. It evaluates universities based on five key pillars: teaching, research environment, research quality, industry engagement, and international outlook. The ranking aims to provide transparency and insights for students, educators, and policymakers across the globe.
MarSU‚Äôs inclusion in this global list is a testament to its growing influence and commitment to academic excellence, research innovation, and global relevance. Most significantly, the university‚Äôs placement reflects its consistent efforts in advancing the United Nations‚Äô 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)‚Äîfrom promoting quality education, gender equality, and climate action, to building partnerships that empower local and international communities.
This achievement affirms MarSU‚Äôs unwavering vision to be a transformative and globally engaged university that fosters inclusive development and sustainable impact. As it joins the ranks of the world‚Äôs recognized institutions, MarSU remains steadfast in its mission to shape future leaders who will contribute meaningfully to a better world

headline.en: MarSU Joins 90th RDC MIMAROPA Full Council Meeting

lead.en: Marinduque State University officials took part in the RDC Full Council Meeting, contributing to key regional development discussions and policy planning.

body.en:
The 90th Regional Development Council (RDC) Full Council Meeting of MIMAROPA was successfully held on June 11, 2025, at The Heritage Hotel Manila, marking another milestone in the region‚Äôs ongoing efforts to enhance cooperation and development. The event brought together key decision-makers and stakeholders, including representatives from national agencies, local government units, and the academe, fostering collaboration and strategic discussions for the region‚Äôs progress. 
Among the notable attendees from the academic sector were officials from Marinduque State University led by its University President, Prof. Diosdado P. Zulueta, accompanied by Assoc. Prof. Alfredo M. Ofrecio III, Chief of Staff and Ms. Mila Grace Gutierrez, Planning Officer III. 
Following the preliminaries, a recognition ceremony was held to honor the outgoing members of the 8th RDC MIMAROPA (2022‚Äì2025), during which plaques and certificates were awarded in appreciation of their contributions. 
The agenda was packed with significant discussions and approvals on policies and programs shaping the socio-economic landsape of the region such as the State of the Region Address (SORA) delivered by RDC Chairperson and Romblon Governor Jose R. Riano; updates on the MIMAROPA Regional Development Investment Program (RDIP) 2023‚Äì2028; endorsements and approvals on strategic infrastructure and social development projects; and introduction of policy reforms and sectoral initiatives focusing on gender, economic planning, and maritime connectivity 
Officials from various government agencies also presented progress reports and updates on regional economic conditions, program monitoring, and policy directions. 
The RDC meeting serves as a platform for aligning regional priorities with national development goals. MarSU‚Äôs involvement in this significant gathering reinforces its vital role not only in providing quality education but also in shaping and supporting development agendas across the MIMAROPA region.

headline.en: MarSU and PCA Explore Strategic Partnership in Agriculture Development

lead.en: MarSU President Prof. Diosdado P. Zulueta met with PCA Administrator Dr. Dexter R. Buted to discuss potential collaborations in coconut research and development.

body.en:
As part of the continuous agriculture development, Prof. Diosdado P. Zulueta (MarSU President), paid a courtesy visit to Dr. Dexter R. Buted, Administrator of the Philippine Coconut Authority (PCA), at the PCA Central Office, Quezon City on June 9, 2025. 
The meeting aimed to explore potential collaborations between MarSU and the PCA, particularly in areas related to coconut research, development, and extension services that can benefit coconut farmers in Marinduque and other coconut-producing provinces. 
Both leaders expressed enthusiasm for possible joint initiatives that align with their shared vision of sustainable agricultural development and community empowerment.

headline.en: MarSU Champions Community Engagement Through Stakeholders' Forum and Impact Assessment Training

lead.en: Marinduque State University successfully held its Stakeholders' Extension Forum and Impact Assessment Training, equipping project leaders and partners with tools to evaluate and enhance community-based initiatives.

body.en:
Marinduque State University (MarSU) continues to champion excellence in  extension and community engagement through its recently concluded 'Stakeholders' Extension Forum and Impact Assessment Training for Extension Projects' through the initiative of the Extension Unit. Held from May 26‚Äì30, 2025 at Rojas Events Place in Santol, Boac, Marinduque, the event brought together a dynamic group of project leaders, extensionists, and representatives from key partner agencies. 
The activity opened with a forum dedicated to engaging stakeholders and aligning extension initiatives with community needs. The following days were devoted to an intensive training on impact assessment, led by two esteemed experts in the field‚ÄîDr. Marilyn M. Elauria, Retired Professor 12 and Dr. Jessie C. Elauria, Retired Professor 12 and UP Scientist I. 
 Participants deepened their understanding of vital concepts through a series of comprehensive topics, such as: 
‚Ä¢ Impact Assessment Framework 
‚Ä¢ Mapping Inputs to Benefits and Adoption Pathways 
‚Ä¢ Sociological and Environmental Approaches in Impact Measurement 
‚Ä¢ Data Collection Techniques 
‚Ä¢ Cost and Return Analysis / Partial Budgeting 
‚Ä¢ Benefit-Cost Approach to Impact Assessment 
Each session featured hands-on activities, allowing participants to apply their learnings to their respective extension projects. The program culminated in the presentation of completed Impact Assessment Project Proposals, showcasing the participants‚Äô enhanced skills in research and evaluation. 
Among the remarkable presentations were: 
‚Ä¢ SAS Journalismo Training Project: An Impact Assessment (College of Arts and Social Sciences) 
‚Ä¢ Impact Assessment on the Training and Production and Usage of a Foot-Operated Hand Sanitizer Dispenser and Handwashing Station (College of Engineering and College of Information and Computing Sciences)
 ‚Ä¢ Brigada-Pagbasa: Teachers Undertaking Reinforcement of Learning (College of Education) 
‚Ä¢ Kaalaman at Katarungan sa Kabarangayan (KKK): A Refresher Training Program for Lupong Tagapamayapa Chairpersons and Members (College of Criminal Justice Education in collaboration with the College of Governance) 
‚Ä¢ Impact Assessment on Technology Adoption on Quality of Bagoong and Patis Production (College  of Fisheries) 
Two proposals were awarded Best Impact Assessment Project: 
üèÜ SAS Journalismo Training Project: An Impact Assessment 
üèÜ KKK: A Refresher Training Program for Lupong Tagapamayapa Chairpersons and Members 
Additionally, the Best Presenter Award was given to Dr. Keam Eric L. Malabayabas of the College of Criminal Justice Education for his outstanding delivery and insightful analysis of the KKK project. 
As the training came to a close, MarSU President Dr. Diosdado P. Zulueta extended his heartfelt gratitude to the participants, organizers, and speakers. He encouraged everyone to integrate the skills and insights gained into their future extension efforts‚Äîunderscoring the university‚Äôs commitment to meaningful impact and inclusive development. 
Through this initiative, MarSU reaffirms its role as a catalyst for transformative community partnerships grounded in research, service, and sustainability.

headline.en: MarSU Adds New Vehicle to Its Fleet

lead.en: Marinduque State University enhances its mobility and operations with the acquisition of a new Toyota pick-up, supporting efficient service delivery across campuses.

body.en:
In a move to enhance operational efficiency and logistical support, the Marinduque State University through its Supply and Property Management Unit officially received the newly procured Toyota Pick-up on April 28, 2025. The acquisition forms part of the institution‚Äôs approved procurement plan for FY 2025, aimed at strengthening mobility services across university operations. 
Following standard procedures, a physical inspection was conducted by the Commission on Audit (COA) on June 2, 2025. The inspection verified that the vehicle matched the technical specifications outlined in the Contract Agreement/Purchase Order. The inspection also ensured that the unit was in good running condition and free from any physical or mechanical defects. 
The University continues to prioritize resource optimization and infrastructure support to improve service delivery. This procurement marks another step forward in maintaining transparency, accountability, and operational excellence.

headline.en: MarSU bags Best R&D Award for Probiotic Drink Innovation

lead.en: Dr. Ma. Edelwina M. Blas√© earned the Best R&D Award for her innovative probiotic drink project using coconut sap, highlighting MarSU‚Äôs commitment to research and human development.

body.en:
In a moment of continuous pursuit for research and innovation, Dr. Ma. Edelwina M. Blas√©, Vice President for Research and Extension, received the esteemed Best R&D Award under Human Development Research Category on May 28, 2025 at the OMSC Gymnasium, Occidental Mindoro, for her pioneering work on the DOST-MIMAROPA-assisted project entitled ‚ÄúDevelopment of a Non-Dairy Probiotic Drink using Coconut Sap as a Substrate‚Äù. 
Dr. Blas√© received the award together with Executive Assistant, Ms. Lenie Z. Rodriguez, who represented MarSU President, Prof. Dr. Diosdado P. Zulueta. Dr. Blas√©‚Äôs dedication to innovation continues to push the boundaries of research, paving the way for advancements in nutrition and wellness. Additionally, MarSU showcased various products from the MarSU Gasan FTBI such as cocobagoong, bagoong, patis and arrowroot pulp products from Arrowroot Project. 
This year‚Äôs 2025 Regional Science, Technology, and Innovation Week featured MIMAROPA Science, Technology, and Innovation Awards, Centerpiece Exhibit, Smarter MSMEs Summit, Beyond Invention: A Look on Market Ready Innovation, Oceans of Opportunity: Innovations for Sustainable Fisheries and Aquaculture; and Building Sustainable and Connected Communities. Part of the team that also attended the event were Ms. Geleen Del Prado from the Arrowroot Project and Dr. Randy T. Nobleza.

headline.en: Marinduque State University Strenghtens Global Linkages through the ASEAN Fellowship Program 2025 in Vietnam

lead.en: Faculty from Marinduque State University took part in the ASEAN Fellowship Program 2025 in Vietnam, exploring innovation and entrepreneurship in future-ready classrooms through workshops, field visits, and international collaboration.

body.en:
MarSU delegation proudly took part in the ASEAN Fellowship Program 2025 hosted by the Saigon Business School (SBS) in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, from May 26‚Äì30, 2025. With the theme 'Future-Ready Classrooms for ASEAN: Integrating Innovation & Entrepreneurship in Teaching,' the program featured a series of dynamic workshops, field visits, and collaborative projects designed to explore innovation and entrepreneurship in higher education. 
Representing the university from the College of Business and Accountancy were the following distinguished faculty members: Assoc. Prof Dr. Verna Liza L. Capi√±a, Assoc. Prof. Generoso E. Udanga, Assoc. Prof. Dr. Merryrose R. Palma, Asst. Prof. Carlo Magno M. Castro, Inst. Gillbert P. Privado, and Inst. Jenyza Dimacali-Rojo. 
Throughout the five-day fellowship, the participants engaged in high-impact sessions ranging from workshops on artificial intelligence in education and curriculum innovation, to field visits to leading businesses and startups in Vietnam. Collaborative group projects also challenged participants to co-create solutions for real-world academic challenges, all while fostering stronger cross-cultural connections and academic cooperation within ASEAN. 
This international engagement forms part of MarSU‚Äôs institutional partnership with Saigon Business School (SBS), further solidifying its commitment to global academic collaboration.  
The MarSU International Relations Office extends its heartfelt gratitude to University President Prof. Dr. Diosdado P. Zulueta for his unwavering support in promoting global competency among our faculty members and for championing global academic opportunities for the MarSU community.

headline.en: Marinduque State University Celebrates Nursing Students‚Äô Achievements in Clinical Graduation

lead.en: MarSU celebrated the clinical graduation of its nursing students, honoring their dedication and readiness to serve in the healthcare field with compassion, integrity, and excellence.

body.en:
On May 30, 2025 Marinduque State University (MarSU), through its College of Allied Health Sciences (CAHS), proudly held its Clinical Graduation for Nursing Students at the University Gymnasium. The ceremony marked a significant milestone in the journey of the university's future healthcare professionals. 
The event commenced with a processional march led by the graduating students, faculty members, university officials, and the esteemed guest of honor. The solemn and celebratory tone of the ceremony was set by the MarSU ROTC Honor Guards. 
The program formally began with Opening Remarks from Assoc. Prof. Julie P. Rodelas, Campus Director. This was followed by the Presentation of the CAHS Faculty of Instruction, led by Assoc. Prof. Marvin P. Plata, Dean of CAHS and Vice President for Student Affairs and Services. Ms. Joy V. Malilay, Associate Dean of CAHS and Program Head of BSN, then led the Presentation of Candidates for Clinical Graduation. 
One of the most pivotal moments of the ceremony was the official confirmation of the clinical graduates by University President, Prof. Diosdado P. Zulueta. Following the confirmation, UPDPZ delivered a heartfelt message to the graduating class: 'This Clinical Graduation is more than a ceremony‚Äîit is a celebration of your courage, your discipline, and your heart for service. You have demonstrated that you are ready not just to heal but to lead, to care, and to serve beyond borders. Let your journey be guided by the values of integrity, compassion, and lifelong learning. MarSU is proud of you‚Äîand we believe in the greatness you will bring into the world of healthcare.' 
The keynote address was delivered by Hon. Zenaida Concepcion-Gagno, a respected member of the Professional Regulation Commission (PRC) Board of Nursing. In her speech, she praised the dedication and resilience of the graduating class and emphasized the essential role of compassion, ethics, and continuous learning in the nursing profession.
A Plaque of Appreciation was then presented to the keynote speaker in recognition of her valuable insights and contributions to the occasion. The program continued with the awarding of certificates of completion and the donning of the sablay, symbolizing the official recognition of the students‚Äô clinical achievements. 
The class response was delivered by Ms. Julianne Vhiera J. Lubay, who expressed heartfelt gratitude to the university, faculty, and families who supported the graduates throughout their academic journey. Asst. Prof. Raoul J. Magcamit, Vice President for Academic Affairs, also extended his warm greetings and congratulations to the graduating class. 
The celebration featured musical interludes, student leadership awards, and touching tributes from faculty and parents, creating an atmosphere of pride and reflection. As these graduates step forward to pursue licensure and enter the professional world of healthcare, MarSU stands proud of its role in shaping not only competent and knowledgeable professionals but also individuals deeply rooted in the core values of integrity, compassion, and service.

headline.en: MarSU Successfully conducts 4th Regular BOR Meeting

lead.en: The Marinduque State University Board of Regents convened to discuss key academic, financial, and administrative matters, reinforcing the university‚Äôs strategic direction and institutional growth.

body.en:
The Marinduque State University (MarSU) Board of Regents (BOR) convened for its 4th Regular Meeting at the Executive Lounge of the Commission on Higher Education (CHED) Central Office in Quezon City on May 28, 2025.  
Key highlights of the meeting included in-depth discussions on financial and fiscal matters, such as proposed financial plans for upcoming university projects. Administrative concerns were also addressed, including proposals to enhance institutional governance and operational efficiency, presented by Atty. Jandusay (VPAF). Additionally, under the academic developments, the Board reviewed new and existing academic programs and faculty development initiatives, including collaborations with foreign institutions which were presented by VPSAS Asso. Prof. Plata and VPAA Asst. Prof. Magcamit. 
The meeting also addressed items for confirmation, such as the appointment of concerned faculty members and administrative personnel, various memorandum of agreement for the implementation of on-the-job training (OJT), and other collaborative undertakings and various agreements for the implementation of research and extension projects. 
Presided over by Hon. Marita R. Canapi, CHED Commissioner and Chairperson of the MarSU BOR, the meeting was attended by Prof. Diosdado P. Zulueta (MarSU President and BOR Vice Chair), Dr. Maria Morena V. Santos (University & Board Secretary), Assoc. Prof. Marvin P. Plata (Vice President for Student Affairs and Services), Hon. Rev. Fr. Ian R. Retardo (Private Sector Representative), Hon. Joy R. Profugo (President of the MarSU Faculty Federation Inc.), and Hon. Nolasco P. Revilla (President of the SSC Federation Inc.), Hon. headline.en: MarSU Forges Stronger Ties With Partners

lead.en: Marinduque State University gathered key partner agencies for a Stakeholders‚Äô Extension Forum, strengthening multi-sectoral collaboration and laying the groundwork for future community-focused extension initiatives.

body.en:
The Marinduque State University (MarSU), through its Extension Office, successfully held the Stakeholders‚Äô Extension Forum on May 26, 2025, during the Day 1 of Stakeholders' Extension Forum and Impact Assessment Training for Extension Projects at Rojas Events Place, Santol, Boac. The event gathered key representatives from various key partner agencies to strengthen inter-agency collaboration and identify areas for future extension partnerships. 
The forum brought together key partner agencies from the Provincial and Municipal Agriculture Offices, Department of Agrarian Reform (DAR), Bureau of Fisheries and Aquatic Resources (BFAR), PNP Marinduque, Department of Environment and Natural Resources (DENR)- PENRO, Department of the Interior and Local Government (DILG), Department of Health (DOH), Department of Education (DepEd), Department of Information and Communications Technology (DICT), Department of Science and Technology (DOST), Department of Trade and Industry (DTI), Technical Education and Skills Development Authority (TESDA) and private stakeholders.
The program opened with a warm welcome from Dr. Ma. Edelwina M. Blase, followed by an inspirational and visionary message from Dr. Diosdado P. Zulueta, President of Marinduque State University. In his message, he expressed his full support for the forum, emphasizing the importance of multi-sectoral collaboration in driving impactful extension initiatives. He reaffirmed the university‚Äôs commitment to community engagement and innovation as key pillars of MarSU‚Äôs development agenda.The highlight of the morning was a keynote address from  
Dr. Angelica Baylon, the Global Chair/ President Emeritus of the Philippine Association of Extension Program Implementers, Inc. (PAEPI), who emphasized the importance of innovation in community extension initiatives.
The forum featured four thematic sessions: 
1. Agriculture and Fisheries Extension Programs for Food Security, presented by PAO, MAO, DAR, and BFAR
2. Community Safety and Environment Protection, presented by DENR 
3. Community Empowerment, Social Protection, and Local Governance, presented by DILG 
4. Innovation, Enterprise Development, and Capacity Building, presented by DOST, DTI, and TESDA 
Each session was followed by an open forum that enabled MarSU and the agencies to engage in dynamic discussions, share best practices, and pinpoint overlapping priorities. This exchange laid the groundwork for collaborative extension projects that address gaps and amplify the impact of each agency‚Äôs initiatives. 
This forum marks a significant step toward a unified and responsive extension framework that empowers communities and enhances service delivery in the province.

headline.en: Marinduque State University Advances Internalization through Key Partnerships at the International COIL Conference 2025

lead.en: Marinduque State University joined the International COIL Conference 2025, forging new partnerships and advancing its commitment to global collaboration and sustainable education.

body.en:
General Santos City ‚Äî Marinduque State University (MarSU) reaffirmed its commitment to global learning and sustainable development by actively participating in the International COIL Conference 2025. Represented by International Relations Director Ms. Jholey Rose R. Lea√±o-Lancion and Executive Assistant Ms. Lenie Z. Rodriguez, MarSU forged new potential partnerships with institutions such as Urdaneta City University, Leyte Normal University, Central Philippine State University, Holy Child Colleges, Inc., and Universitas Islam Bandung, Indonesia. 
These collaborations align with the United Nations‚Äô Sustainable Development Goals, focusing on quality education and strong partnerships, and mark MarSU‚Äôs formal commitment to the Bayanihan COIL Network initiative of CHED-IAS. The partnerships aim to launch collaborative COIL projects in the coming academic year, strengthening internationalization by bridging local and global academic communities. 
MarSU extends gratitude to University President Prof. Dr. Diosdado P. Zulueta for his steadfast support in advancing the university‚Äôs international initiatives.

headline.en: MarSU Top 9 Best Performing School in LPT (Secondary Level)

lead.en: Marinduque State University proudly celebrates its recognition as the 9th Best Performing School in the Licensure Examination for Teachers (Secondary Level)‚Äîa true testament to the excellence, dedication, and heart of its education community.

body.en:
With immense pride and overwhelming joy, we celebrate Marinduque State University's incredible achievement‚ÄîTop 9 Best Performing School in the Licensure Examination for Teachers (Secondary Level)! 
This victory is not just a ranking‚Äîit is a testament to the relentless passion, unwavering dedication, and unbreakable spirit of our educators, students, and leaders who pour their hearts into shaping the future of education. Every sleepless night, every sacrifice, every challenge faced head-on has led to this moment of triumph. 
To our aspiring teachers, you are the beacon of hope for the generations to come, carrying the noble mission of education forward with excellence and integrity. To our faculty and staff, your unwavering commitment and guidance have transformed dreams into reality. 
MarSU, this milestone is proof that greatness is not just achieved‚Äîit is built with love, perseverance, and an unyielding belief in the power of education! 
Congratulations, College of Education! 
Mabuhay, MarSU! Your journey to greater heights continues!

headline.en: Marinduque State University Integrated High School Holds 8th Commencement and 10th Moving-Up Ceremony

lead.en: Marinduque State University celebrated the achievements of its Junior and Senior High School students in a heartfelt ceremony led by President Prof. Diosdado P. Zulueta, honoring graduates, completers, and their families.

body.en:
On May 15, 2025, the Marinduque State University (MarSU) Integrated High School proudly celebrated its 8th Commencement Exercise and 10th Moving-Up Ceremony at the MarSU Gymnasium in Boac, honoring the academic achievements of its graduates and completers from the Junior and Senior High School departments. 
The ceremony was graced by the presence of MarSU President, Prof. Diosdado P. Zulueta, who also officiated the confirmation of graduates and completers. He delivered an inspiring and heartfelt message to the graduates, moving-up students, and their families. 
In his official message, Prof. Zulueta recognized the crucial role of families in the academic journey of the students, stating: 
‚ÄúTo the proud parents and guardians, your love, sacrifices, and guidance have been essential to the success of your children. Ang tagumpay nila ay tagumpay rin ninyo.‚Äù 
Joining President Zulueta at this momentous event were key university officials. Vice President for Research, Extension, and Training, Dr. Ma. Edelwina M. Blas√©, Vice President for Academic Affairs, Asst. Prof. Raoul J. Magcamit, Vice President for Student Affairs and Services, Assoc. Prof. Marvin P. Plata, University Registrar, Ms. Gemma Tirol. Also in attendance were the academic leaders and faculty members from the College of Education, led by Dean Dr. Joy S. Montejo, and the Integrated High School, headed by Dr. Noel R. Palomares. 
The gymnasium was filled with the joyful presence of proud parents, families, students, and invited guests, all gathered to witness this important academic milestone. The program featured the presentation of candidates for graduation and moving-up, the awarding of certificates and diplomas, and the awarding of academic honors.
